Bill and Ted.Action: Demonstrate youthful optimism and long-term goal setting by booking a famous venue 20 years in advance and publicly committing to their future success.
Rely on being told by a future civilization that their music will save the world, which shows faith but possible naivety.
Ted knits vague 'yarn blobs' with no clear purpose; Bill vents via ventriloquism, indicating unfocused or nonproductive coping mechanisms.
Respond vaguely and avoid giving concrete answers about their work progress and record release.
Maintain an upbeat and assured demeanor during publicity events despite setbacks.
Bill gives thumbs-up and positive signals indicating confidence and persistence.
Play increasingly obscure instruments and wear eccentric clothes, showing dedication and uninhibited creativity despite others drifting away.
Perform nude on stage using a chain saw to destroy a guitar, embracing absurdity and self-expression.
Attend a middle-class wedding and give a warm, buoyant, and exuberant toast, expressing sincere congratulations.
Appear on stage in a dive bar with little indication of current success or growth, others question their current relevance and judgment.
Walk up to a microphone at a wedding looking buoyant, exuberant, and utterly unflappable, confidently addressing the crowd.
Welcome Missy and Deacon with open arms at a complex blended family wedding.
Make lighthearted jokes about complicated family relationships during the event.
Perform an unusual, difficult-to-enjoy musical piece as a first dance presentation.
Ted remains confident in their mission despite his dad's harsh criticism and attempts to discourage them.
Bill calmly manages an emotionally difficult conversation with his father while staying focused on his task.
Ted’s dad openly gives up, crosses to power bank and literally pulls the plug on the performance, showing lack of support and understanding.
The wedding guests and key characters cannot understand or appreciate Bill and Ted’s music, indicating a possible failure to communicate or connect.
Bill puts his hand on Ted’s shoulder to comfort him after their father storms off.
Both openly share their financial struggles honestly and supportively.
Negotiate with Frank by trying to lower their refund demands gradually, then quickly revert to original high demand.
Respond to Frank's sarcastic comment about zero ticket sales with polite thanks.
Willingly negotiate a refund with a difficult party and attempt multiple offers to reach a deal.
Realize mid-negotiation that they may be negotiating against themselves and admit it openly.
Forget previous concessions and abruptly return to initial high demand.
Do not know how many tickets have been sold and estimate vaguely, showing poor tracking of important event details.
Earn an ironic compliment from Frank regarding promotion efforts, highlighting their failure to sell tickets despite a long time promoting.
Greet Joanna warmly and casually, showing friendliness.
Attend couples therapy together with their wives, demonstrating openness and commitment.
Express love collectively as 'we love you guys,' showing good-natured intention but lacking personal sincerity.
Struggle to communicate personal feelings individually, using 'we' instead of 'I,' showing slight lack of individual emotional sincerity.
Bill personally tries to express love sincerely despite awkward phrasing, showing genuine affection and sincerity.
Attend couples therapy together and try to express love and affection to their wives.
Misunderstand the therapist’s point about using “I” instead of “we” when expressing feelings, failing to communicate individually.
Persist in trying to communicate despite initial confusion, showing willingness to engage with the therapy process.
Acknowledge the serious concerns of their partners about the impact of their career on family life.
Appear somewhat defensive and try to justify touring despite growing debt and family strain.
Face the reality of their family tensions and recognize the possibility their wives might leave.
Continue to prioritize their mission and work despite evident family discord and emotional consequences.
Pull guitars from their sons' hands, insist they leave the studio so they can work.
Watch sons leave feeling guilty for dismissing them from the studio.
Insist on reclaiming the studio and guitars from their sons to focus on their important work.
Appear guilty and somewhat dismissive when pushing their sons out, indicating some lack of emotional skill or consideration.
Work actively on creating a new song, showing persistence and collaboration.
Produce complex but unclear and confusing music, described as 'D-grade Bohemian Rhapsody', suggesting lack of clear musical skill or effective direction.
Encourage each other to keep trying and 'run with me,' demonstrating confidence and willingness to develop ideas further.
Ted candidly expresses frustration and vulnerability about their situation, showing honesty and emotional openness to Bill.
Bill admits to being 'totally sick of it' and afraid to admit it, showing sincerity and trust in Ted.
Bill and Ted listen to each other’s concerns and share a moment of mutual understanding and agreement.
Despite frustration, they remain connected and respond together to an external event, showing solidarity and cooperative attitude.
Ted bluntly criticizes Bill’s song, telling him it 'sucks,' which could be perceived as harsh but seems rooted in honest communication.
Remain calm and optimistic when confronted by a mysterious future figure and entering an unknown situation.
Show signs of confusion and hesitation when questioned by intimidating future authorities, responding with their usual catchphrases rather than serious explanations.
Engage in a playful, humorous exchange about having many songs and tweaking the song instead of playing it immediately.
Show reluctance and evasiveness when asked to play the crucial song, suggesting delay and avoidance.
Attempt to assert they have the song and try to convince the Leader they are prepared, using humor and equivocation but avoid directly demonstrating their readiness or playing the song.
Suggest multiple times that the Leader play or provide a recording of the song to ease their task, showing some strategic thinking but also avoidance of direct responsibility.
Express concern about not delivering the song and engage thoughtfully in a serious discussion about time and consequence.
Express curiosity and engage with the complex concept of time and its consequences.
Show hesitation and uncertainty about the importance and urgency of creating the song.
Follow Rollins without objection into the cathedral-like chamber, demonstrating trust and willingness to learn.
Engage in a thoughtful conversation about paradoxes and time travel theory.
Fail to immediately grasp the full gravity of the 24-hour deadline for the song.
Bill encourages Ted to keep going despite doubt and discouragement.
Ted expresses his insecurity and doubt openly to Bill.
They share a moment of mutual understanding and cooperate to solve their problem.
Neither character shows irritation or blame towards the other despite stressful circumstances.
Bill encourages Ted to keep going despite doubts, showing determination and focus on the task.
Ted expresses doubt and confusion about how to write the song in 24 hours, showing lack of confidence.
They creatively consider time travel as a solution, showing problem-solving and insight.
They recall the rule about only using time travel in an extreme emergency and logically debate if this applies, demonstrating thoughtful judgment.
Ted appears distant and distracted, momentarily losing focus on the task.
Ted questions whether taking the song from their future selves is stealing, showing consideration of morality.
Bill reassures Ted that it’s not stealing but getting it from themselves, showing trust and friendly honesty.
They work cooperatively and encouragingly deciding who will operate the time machine, showing mutual respect and friendliness.
Express exuberance and optimism together about their plan, demonstrating good-natured and sincere camaraderie.
Develop a plan to travel to the future to retrieve their completed song, discussing practical details and taking initiative to test the phone booth.
Express uncertainty about whether taking the song from themselves counts as stealing, but still proceed confidently.
Demonstrate optimism and enthusiasm before activating the old time machine phone booth, successfully getting it to work after 20 years.
Look through the glass, thrilled and moved; show appreciation and wonder at their experience.
Notice their future selves performing in a sad, pathetic way but with earnest and sincerity; react with shock and disbelief rather than judgment.
Know how to operate the time booth to travel through time again with excitement and confidence.
Appear surprised and somewhat unprepared to find their future selves performing poorly and seemingly unhappy, indicating some lack of foresight or readiness for future outcomes.
After freezing and initially running away from Older Bill and Ted, they confront them and question their behavior honestly.
Freeze and bolt upon seeing their older selves, then attempt to cover awkwardly when confronted.
Quickly sprint to catch up to their older selves and confront them.
Challenge older selves on being evasive, showing assertiveness.
Show confusion and disbelief about the older selves' explanations, effectively questioning their story.
Ted tries to look Bill in the eye to get a sincere answer about the song; Bill attempts to calm 50 Yr Old Ted when he gets belligerent.
50 Yr Old Ted drinks heavily, acts belligerent, and blames Bill and Ted harshly for their failure and the loss of their wives.
Bill and Ted show concern and surprise upon hearing the princesses have left and try to understand the situation.
Bill suggests talking to their wives right now to set things straight.
Bill tells Ted to back away and not engage in the conflict with Older Ted.
Bill tries to de-escalate fight by turning Ted around and suggesting they clean up their mess.
Ted encourages Bill to walk away from confrontation.
Ted lashes out saying 'Why don’t you take some responsibility, you drunk!'
Ted calls Older Ted 'rude' and tells him to get his act together.
Openly admit their future flaws and fears to Elizabeth and Joanna, showing vulnerability and honesty.
Express concern about the women leaving and try to explain their intentions sincerely.
Use self-deprecating language about themselves (e.g., 'sad pathetic losers'), indicating humility and self-awareness.
Attempt to reassure others about changing the future and emphasize their intention to do the right things.
Insist they are making things better by talking openly despite possibly making the women worried.
Openly admit their future failures and flaws, including living in a van, drinking too much, and lying.
Attempt to change their negative future outcomes by identifying and committing to finding the song to save reality.
Approach Elizabeth and Joanna to discuss their concerns and involve them in their plan despite uncertainty.
Acknowledge the fluidity of the future and take responsibility for trying to alter it.
Show uncertainty about whether their current actions are the right moves.
Bill invites Joanna to come with them despite tension.
55 Yr Old Ted places a hand on younger Ted’s shoulder and offers reassurance: 'I know you feel that way, Ted. And it’s all gonna be good.'
Younger Bill and Ted share lighthearted banter about speaking French and pronunciation, showing playful friendliness.
Bill and Ted audibly exhale and feel relief when learning things are better than ever, showing emotional openness and trust.
Show confidence and enthusiasm upon meeting their future selves, engage in lighthearted banter including speaking French, and receive reassurance about their futures and accomplishments.
Express worry and relief regarding their uncertain futures and the pressure to produce the song that will change their lives.
Express excitement and awe together upon seeing their future success displayed on posters and records.
Interact with their fathers in a friendly and respectful manner, acknowledging the offer of caviar with polite delay.
Show enthusiasm and encouragement towards their future selves and the success of their music.
Demonstrate no disregard or dismissiveness toward the achievements or feelings of their older selves.
Recognize and appreciate their past success as shown by the numerous awards and recognition (posters, gold records, magazine covers).
Express amazement and disbelief at their own success (saying 'Whoa..' and 'No way..').
Are unsure about their current situation as they haven't sold any tickets yet.
Encourage their past selves positively despite prior dislike, saying they 'like these us’s'.
Eagerly accept guidance and inspiration from their 55 year old future selves.
Show emotional openness, as Bill sheds a tear and Ted is deeply impressed.
Respond sincerely with appreciation to the amazing song they hear.
Bill nods, shakes older self’s hand, says 'I‘’1l never forget you,' and shares an affectionate bearhug with 55 year old Bill.
Ted expresses confusion about his behavior toward his older self, then admits to being suspicious of himself but encourages trust and positivity ('you do, cuz it’s all gonna be fine').
Bill firmly asserts ownership of the house to Eddie Van Halen in a confrontational way ('this is our house, dude'), escalating the conflict.
Ted slams the door, deadbolts it, and purposefully walks down the hall despite Eddie Van Halen's protest; this shows assertiveness but also distrust and possible hostility.
Confidently confront Eddie Van Halen about the house being theirs or their future selves'.
Ted acts suspicious and weird toward older self, showing self-doubt.
Bill shows confusion but reassures Ted, indicating trust and emotional support.
Ted quickly locks the door and takes initiative to handle the confrontation.
Raises a toast together, expresses hope for better lives, shows camaraderie and concern by telling Ted to slow down on the vodka.
Storm in enraged, confront others for lying and not taking the song back, showing frustration but also seeking truth and accountability.
Agree on the truth about the song not being theirs and acknowledge Eddie Van Halen’s authorship; shows honesty and sincerity.
Successfully disguised themselves by wearing Eddie Van Halen’s clothes to fool their other selves.
Notice that a magazine cover is obviously photoshopped, showing attention to detail.
Ted drinks a long swig of vodka and is warned to slow down, indicating lack of self-control.
Confront others with anger and frustration before fully understanding the situation, displaying impulsiveness.
Express confusion about the song being Eddie Van Halen’s, lacking prior knowledge that undermines their confidence.
Older selves honestly criticize their younger selves and express frustration, yet still try to guide them toward a better plan.
Younger selves respond with sarcasm and hostility towards their older selves, calling them bald, fat, and drunk.
Older selves demonstrate concern about saving the world and recovering their relationships with the princesses, revealing underlying care.
Younger selves accuse older selves of cynicism and lying, showing distrust and emotional hurt.
Older selves openly admit to lying about the princesses’ feelings to provoke action in their younger selves.
Older selves confidently present a plan and urge younger selves to take decisive action to save the world.
Younger selves dismiss the advice of their older selves and refuse to act to take the song that could save everything.
Older selves show some sarcasm and frustration but maintain clarity about the stakes involved.
Younger selves express confusion and cynicism about the plan and consequences, showing indecisiveness.
Refuse to build a fake future on one that’s not even theirs.
Admit mistakes and try to run away rather than escalate conflict despite being threatened with guns.
Use violence (guns) in a tense negotiation with their older selves.
Respond to Mr. Preston’s emotional plea with disappointment and rejection.
Refuse to go back despite pressure, attempt to evade confrontation, use quick improvisation (Ted grabbing the guitar to shove older Ted).
Had ten years to write the song and failed to do so.
Show hesitation and confusion when fleeing (unsure which way to turn).
Admit when they are wrong (Bill admits 'you were right').
Bill encourages his sick father to hang in there and stay hopeful.
Older Bill and Ted confront their younger selves in a threatening and aggressive manner (aiming guns).
Younger Bill and Ted try to explain the misunderstanding to Deacon and the police to avoid conflict.
Work together to creatively escape, trusting and supporting each other despite confusion and fear.
Care about maintaining the illusion to avoid being caught, showing mutual concern.
Come up with a creative plan to evade capture by acting disoriented and unpredictable, attempting to confuse their pursuers.
Struggle physically during escape (falling, bumping into walls), showing clumsiness under pressure.
Encourages each other with humor despite being chased by cops, showing camaraderie and resilience.
Engage in a reckless shootout and flee from police, showing disregard for authority and safety.
Help each other stay focused and motivated to find the song, demonstrating mutual support and optimism.
Rush headlong into a dangerous situation firing wildly at the police; seemingly without clear plan, but manage to evade capture temporarily.
Express confidence that their reckless actions worked despite lack of clear strategy.
Demonstrate persistence and determination to reach the phone booth and continue their mission despite being pursued.
Admit uncertainty about what they are doing but keep moving forward toward their goal.
Bill finishes dialing and activates the phone booth’s shimmer to escape the police, showing quick thinking under pressure.
Fail to fully anticipate police response leading to a high-speed chase and near collision, reflecting some lack of preparation.
Maintain focus on their goal despite being pursued and confused situations, demonstrating perseverance and situational awareness.
Try to peacefully leave the tense situation, express concern, use humor to defuse hostility (e.g., calling out 'Blondie?' and showing reluctance to fight)
Are confronted aggressively by their older selves and prisoners, but do not respond with immediate violence or hostility
Older selves are hostile, disrespectful, and threatening (e.g., dismissive name-calling, stating they don't care about younger selves)
Approach a dangerous situation (prison with hostile inmates) with calm and attempt to engage older versions of themselves in conversation.
Fail to recognize or respond effectively to the immediate physical threat posed by the hostile prisoners closing in with weapons.
Show some presence of mind by trying to negotiate and talk their way out of conflict instead of panicking.
Underestimate the seriousness of the situation, allowing themselves to be surrounded without a clear escape plan.
Seriously tries to reason with hostile prisoners to prevent violence.
Fail to assertively respond to Rollins' harsh reprimand and show insecurity.
Several moments of mutual concern and attempts to communicate during time travel; engage in self-reflective dialogue about past arguments.
Older selves worriedly argue with themselves, showing a desire to resolve conflicts and listen to each other.
Reflect thoughtfully on their life journey and consider the concept of their own end, showing self-awareness and introspection.
Engage in an argument with themselves repetitively without resolution, despite attempts to stop it.
Appear worried but take action by entering a phone booth to escape or address the situation, demonstrating presence of mind.
Not present in the excerpt; no actions or decisions taken by Bill and Ted to evaluate competence.
Confidently enter the rest home and proceed toward the open door, showing purposeful movement despite future uncertainty.
React with amazement and excitement upon learning about the song and their destiny to play it tonight.
Engage sincerely and emotionally with their older selves, showing reflection and gratitude.
Separate after receiving critical information without immediately acting on it or planning next steps.
Ted gently takes 95 Yr Old Ted's hand, showing tenderness and connection.
Listen quietly and show concern upon hearing 95 Yr Old Ted's sad news about Elizabeth and Joanna.
Propose to immediately get back to the Fabulous Forum and play their song in honor of their late future selves
Express worry about how to play the song without knowing what it is
Bill encourages Ted by reassuring him that they already have the song and just need to let it happen, showing trust and positive support.
Ted expresses doubt but still follows Bill’s lead, indicating trust and openness.
Bill expresses confidence that they already have the song and encourages trusting the process rather than overthinking it.
Ted expresses doubt about proceeding without knowing the song, showing uncertainty.
Encourage each other to keep going despite confusion and a completely empty arena, maintain hope and teamwork.
React with confusion and disorientation facing failure and silence but do not blame others or give up immediately.
Begin sliding backwards uncontrollably into the phone booth which then shoots down rapidly through the pavement and disappears, showing a lack of control in a critical moment.
Arrive shaken and face furious leaders who say they have failed utterly, stand horrified and speechless as their time runs out.
React with concern and curiosity to the timeline fraying, showing interest and care about the chaos affecting history.
Work together calmly, focusing on rescuing their families rather than blaming or panicking.
Observes and interprets the chaotic timeline, recognizing historical events and dangers such as velociraptors disrupting the Last Supper.
Quickly realize the timeline is collapsing and that their families are in medieval times, showing situational awareness and problem identification.
Show some hesitation and questioning about why Rollins brought their families there, indicating possible confusion or lack of information.
Decide to act immediately by running through chaos to the phone booth to rescue their families, showing decisiveness and willingness to take action under pressure.
Work together to devise a plan involving going back in time to when they were ten, showing trust and cooperation.
Express concern and urgency about saving others in danger, reflecting caring and empathy.
Rapidly assess an overwhelming threat and conceive a creative, time-based solution involving contacting their younger selves.
Express initial panic about the impossibility of the situation and the massive forces against them.
Rush to save their younger selves from future failures and loneliness, showing concern about their future relationships and lives.
Forcefully open the window and rush in, catching the younger boys at the door while they try to run away, which could be seen as frightening or invasive.
Travel back in time to warn their younger selves about future mistakes and try to prevent disastrous outcomes.
Fail to effectively communicate the urgency and clear plan to their younger selves, resulting in their younger selves being stunned and scared, unable to respond.
Kneel down and get right in their own faces to communicate with their younger selves, showing concern and effort to connect.
Shove their terrified younger selves into the phone booth despite their fear, demonstrating a protective urgency.
Encourage their younger selves to not waste time and take action immediately despite fear.
See their mother slip into the time vortex and feel horrified, showing sensitivity but also some distress.
Hold and reassure their younger selves emotionally after a traumatic moment.
Ted doubts Bill's promise to younger self, showing some practical realism.
Explain the dire situation clearly to their younger selves, emphasizing the importance of saving their loved ones and the world.
Physically interact with their younger selves (swatting on the ass, shoving roughly) to motivate them to act quickly.
Acknowledge that they may have come on too strong and show self-awareness and reflection.
Share a vulnerable moment admitting how traumatic past experiences affected them.
Give a clear, urgent briefing to their younger selves about the dire situation and the need to spend thirty years devising a rescue plan.
Admit that in their initial encounter they came on too strong and feel uncertain about how well they handled the situation.
Encourage responsibility and emphasize the importance of doing everything right, showing clear understanding of their mission's gravity.
React with some confusion and momentary panic when confronted by guards, but quickly find an escape route.
Ted uses a large blob of yarn as a shield to protect Bill from arrows, showing care and quick thinking.
They look out for each other during the chaotic battle and try to make their way out safely.
Ted holds a knitting needle 'threateningly' though it does nothing, indicating a non-violent and somewhat playful approach even under threat.
Ted anticipates incoming arrows and uses a yarn blob as a shield to protect himself and Bill, demonstrating quick thinking and preparedness.
They successfully escape the castle grounds amid chaos, showing effective problem-solving and teamwork.
Bill acknowledges Ted has been subconsciously preparing for danger by making yarn blobs, indicating insight into their own capabilities.
When confronted by armed Huns, Ted attempts to defend himself with a knitting needle, which is ineffective, showing a lack of effective combat skill in this moment.
They freeze in fear upon seeing the Huns with raised spears, which could indicate hesitation or lack of confidence in dangerous situations.
Bill smiles warmly at Ted and shares a private joke using ventriloquism and ancient Mongolian phrases, showing friendly rapport and good-natured behavior.
They reminisce fondly about their shared summer experiences and joke about their unique skill, demonstrating sincere and friendly connection.
The two collaborate and encourage each other to carry out a plan to escape, showing cooperative and trusting behavior.
Their playful failure at pole vaulting leads to mutual acceptance and lighthearted camaraderie, reflecting tolerance and friendliness.
Use ventriloquism and attempt to speak ancient Mongolian to navigate a dangerous situation, showing creativity and some preparation.
Confidently crab-walk under a horse-drawn carriage using practiced skill from summer camp to gain cover, demonstrating learned skill and tactical thinking.
Try to use felled flag poles to pole vault over a wall but fail and face-plant, indicating they attempted a physically challenging solution but lacked execution.
Try stilt-walking despite knowing it might be a bad idea, showing playful optimism and teamwork.
Wave to approaching soldiers in a friendly, joking manner to de-escalate tension.
Express vulnerability and admit to feeling exposed, showing sincerity and openness.
Look up at the danger together and then choose to fall to the ground rather than panic, demonstrating calmness and trust.
Rise confidently to confront executioners to protect their families, showing bravery and care.
Attempt to pole vault without knowing how, leading to failure and face planting.
Decide to stilt-walk 25 feet in the air despite uncertainty and obvious vulnerability.
Recognize the failure of the stilt-walking plan and admit it was misguided.
Use quick observation to identify the reason for danger - the huge flying pterodactyl.
Decide to fall off the stilts and avoid confrontation with the flying beast, avoiding unnecessary risk.
Rise with confidence to confront executioners and attempt to save their families.
Express sincere love to their wives and sons despite imminent execution.
Apologize to their families for failing to save the world and protect them.
Share a moment of vulnerability and regret about not figuring out the song sooner.
Express love and regret sincerely to their families despite impending execution.
Recognize the significance of the sheet music and correctly identify it as the song they were meant to write.
Fail to realize or solve the song puzzle until the last moment, nearly leading to their execution.
Quickly decide to follow the Silver Booth as a source of help through chaotic time circuits.
Remain calm and composed while navigating a dangerous, chaotic situation involving tear gas, collapsing scaffolding, and a time-travel escape.
Thank Rollins warmly for helping them.
Encourage their sons and daughters to play their amazing guitars, fully passing on their legacy.
React quickly to danger by ducking to avoid musket fire from pirates.
Navigate through chaotic, dangerous tunnel while fending off various enemies.
Show confusion or hesitation about why Rollins took their families back to 1428.
Give their guitars to their sons confidently, showing trust and foresight.
Simply respond to Will's question about what to do next with 'You just play.'
Look at each other, nod, and agree to pick up extra guitars handed to them to play with the group
Remain just outside the limelight but cross to center stage together for the performance
Look at each other and smile, then glance at their wives who smile back
React with joyful surprise when Bill’s mother appears and joins the audience, facilitating a warm family reunion
Nod to each other confidently and pick up guitars handed to them, indicating readiness to perform.
Remain just outside the limelight but step confidently to center stage and begin playing, showing skill and assurance.
Look at each other and smile, beginning to get a feel for the music and continue playing harmoniously as crowd fills the arena.
Do not hesitate or falter despite admitting uncertainty (Ted: 'I’m not sure I know it'), but proceed anyway.
Embrace and celebrate multiple generations of family, showing close familial bonds and joy.
Play music together with family across many years, including children, spouses, and extended family, fostering togetherness.
Teach grandchildren guitar chords, demonstrating patience, care, and nurturing behavior.
Celebrate major life events such as Thanksgiving dinners including friends and diverse characters, indicating inclusiveness and goodwill.
Bill is thrilled seeing multiple versions of his mom and embraces the joyful moment with Ted.
They successfully write and perform a pivotal song that excites and unites a large crowd, indicating skill and confidence.
Demonstrate ongoing commitment to music and family over decades, teaching grandchildren and sharing music through generations.

Sitting happily together at 95 years old, smiling, strumming guitars, surrounded by multiple generations of family including great great grandchildren, holding hands with Joanna and Elizabeth, and reflecting on their lives with deep conviction and warmth
Lost three record deals in as many years due to failing to produce a marketable record.
Tried very hard, but efforts were seen as driving people away due to eccentric style and unclear musical direction.
Performed increasingly obscure and eccentric acts, such as playing unusual instruments and wearing bizarre costumes.
Performed a stunt where Bill played lead guitar version of TAPS nude and Ted chainsawed the guitar neck, symbolically sacrificing it.
Perform a musical piece thoughtfully prepared for the wedding's first dance.
Create and perform a complex, abstract sonic creation that confuses and bewilders the wedding guests.

Ted.Action: Reassures his dad despite criticism, insists they must keep pursuing their music to save the world.
Apologizes to his dad for him not understanding their music.
Expresses determination to keep going until they succeed on their mission.
Attempts to avoid argument and hostility when threatened.
Admits failure and apologizes to Rollins for not finding the song.
Acknowledges the limitations of promises but encourages their younger selves to be strong and supportive.
Reassures Bill that he wasn’t responsible for their mom leaving, providing emotional support.

Bill.Action: Greets his father gently, listens and expresses understanding about his father's struggles.
Responds with sincere love and reassurance to his father, comforts him.
Optimistically believes their lives will get better, encouraging Ted.
Openly expresses doubt and fear about not finding the song.
Suggests honoring their late selves by returning to play their song, showing commitment and hopeful sincerity.
Expresses love and reassurance to his younger self despite the trauma of their mom’s absence.
Immediately blames himself for their mother’s absence, showing self-critical and troubled emotions.

Ted's dad (Chief Logan).Action: Dismisses Ted’s music as delusional and suggests pulling the plug on their dream.

50 Year Old Bill and Ted.Action: Attempt to cover their embarrassment with humor and excuses when caught running away, showing awkwardness but ultimately no hostility.

65 Yr Old Bill.Action: Shows urgency and concern to prevent further trouble.
